Introduction

This policy aims to support the Trust occupational health department in managing TB screening and immunisation for healthcare workers. It aims to facilitate implementation of the Department of Health (DH) 2006 publication “Immunisation against Infectious Diseases”, the DH Guidelines “Health clearance for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, hepatitis C and HIV: New healthcare workers” and the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) Guidelines on Clinical Diagnosis and Management of Tuberculosis and measures for its prevention and Control CG117.

These documents complement obligations under the Health and Safety at Work etc Act (1974) and related guidance on immunisation and testing of healthcare workers who are at risk of acquiring Tuberculosis (TB).
TB is a prescribed disease for healthcare workers. It is a Notifiable Disease as required under the Public Health (Infectious Diseases) Act 1988.
Tuberculosis is a complex condition. It is highly prevalent across the world. It is recognised that healthcare workers (HCWs) are at a small but significantly increased risk of contracting TB.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
To prevent and manage the risk of a Health Care Worker (HCW) developing tuberculosis (TB) from patient contact.
To prevent and manage the exposure of TB in HCWs
To outline the health surveillance and reporting mechanisms for those staff who are regularly exposed to patients with TB or who work in high risk clinical environments for exposure to TB
Definitions

table_items.text: Bacillus Calmette-Guerin Vaccine Health care worker
Interferon Gamma Test (either Quantiferon Gold or T-Spot).
Tuberculin Skin Test (either Heaf of Mantoux)
Tuberculin Units (applies to the Mantoux Test: either 2TU or 10 TU)

data.text: Roles and responsibilities
Infection Control Committee is responsible for receiving information from and advising on:
Reports of infections and infection control issues including national reports and initiatives that may affect patient or staff health;
Effectiveness of the arrangements in for contact tracing.
Health & Safety Committee reviews the effectiveness of the arrangements in place to manage the risks associated with vaccine-preventable diseases by
Processing reports received by Occupational Health;
Reporting numbers of staff appropriately vaccinated against target to directorate heads.
Chief Executive

The Chief Executive will ensure, as far as reasonably practicable, the health and wellbeing of its staff whilst at work. This duty includes ensuring reasonable steps are in place to ensure that staff are protected from the risk of TB.
The Trust will, as far as reasonably practicable maintain a safe place of work, safe systems of work and a safe and healthy working environment.
Workforce
Duties Are:

Employees new to the NHS who will be working with patients or clinical specimens should not start work until they have completed a TB screen or health check, or until documentary evidence is provided of such screening having taken place within the preceding  months

It is the responsibility of the Workforce department, through their recruitment team, to ensure that all prospective candidates complete a pre-placement health questionnaire prior to commencement of employment.
Occupational Health
Occupational Health will screen all new staff prior to employment in line with Department of Health/NICE guidelines on TB.
They will ensure that the Workforce department are informed of the fitness status of all pre-employment candidates.

Immunisation history and status of all new starters will be checked. A visual check will be undertaken to determine the presence or otherwise of a TB immunisation scar. This will be recorded in the employee's occupational health record.
TB symptoms reminders will be sent annually to all staff who are at increased risk.
Occupational Health will provide information about TB screening, symptoms and the need for prompt reporting.
Line Managers

Managers will ensure that all new employees attend Occupational Health within the first two days of commencement of employment and that they are given time during working hours to attend occupational health for immunisation and other appointments.

They must undertake risk assessments in regards to risk of exposure to TB in high- risk clinical areas and ensure that staff are aware of those risks and the procedure for reporting any personal health concerns that suggest infection with TB.
They must undertake risk assessments in regards to risk of exposure to TB for any member of staff who declines or is unable to have the BCG.
Staff
Staff are expected to comply with the Occupational Health Department's procedure for screening of TB as set out in this policy. ]

They should report any signs and symptoms and concerns they may be experiencing that suggest infection with TB to occupational health as soon as possible and seek medical advice for treatment. They should report to Occupational Health for assessment if they have been outside of the UK visiting a high risk area for more than 4 weeks.
They should be aware that BCG does not confer complete protection and TB cases still occur in vaccinated HCWs.
Staff who know they are HIV positive, or believe they are at increased risk, should seek specific guidance from occupational health.
Infection Prevention and Control Teams
They should provide up to date advice and education on infection control indications for respiratory PPE, based on current research that supports good infection control practice.
They should ensure that infection control guidelines for respiratory PPE usage are followed.
They should notify occupational health of any possible risks to staff following identification of any previously undiagnosed TB cases admitted to the wards.
Clinical information
Disease

Human tuberculosis (TB) is an infection with bacteria of the mycobacterium tuberculosis complex (M. Tuberculosis, M. bovis or M. africanum) and usually affects the lungs (pulmonary TB). It may however affect almost any other part of the body. The initial infection may be eliminated (heal spontaneously), remain latent (where the individual has no symptoms but the TB bacteria remains in the body) or progress to active TB over weeks or months. Latent TB may reactivate in later life particularly if the individual is immunocompromised either by disease or medical treatment. With few exceptions, only those who develop active TB in the lungs or larynx can infect others, usually by coughing or sneezing (droplet infection). Such transmission is only likely when the index case is smear-positive for the bacillus and after prolonged close contact. It can also be acquired through ingestion of contaminated milk (M. bovis).

TB usually requires prolonged close contact for transmission of infection from person to person. The recent evidence in the NHS suggests that the risk of transmission from patient to HCW is very low. Studies indicate that nearly 80% of cases in HCWs occur in those born in high TB prevalent countries. The majority of these occur after the individuals have lived in the UK for several years. Therefore this group should be carefully screened for latent infection.
People at increased risk from developing active disease include:
People at the extremes of age
Immunosuppressed patients for example patients with acute leukaemia, lymphoma or organ transplants
Patients with concomitant HIV infection
Homelessness
Chronic alcohol abuse
Belonging to an ethnic group from high prevalence countries
Patients at increased risk of transmitting TB are:
Those who fail to comply with infection control guidelines
Those with productive coughs unable to cover their noses and mouth when coughing and sneezing
Those patients with tracheostomies
Clinical Features Symptoms
The onset of TB is generally insidious, with infection proceeding for some time before the patient becomes sufficiently ill to seek medical advice.
Clinical manifestations are variable, but include:
Fatigue
Weight loss
Weakness
Night sweats
Fever
For pulmonary TB there is a characteristically chronic productive cough with blood stained sputum.
Diagnosis of active TB
Diagnosis will normally be confirmed by a Chest Physician rather than OH. Treatment
Treatment of TB is the responsibility of the Chest Physician.
Prognosis
Untreated TB in otherwise healthy adults is normally a slowly progressive disease that may eventually be fatal. However, with effective treatment it is possible to make a full recovery.
Vaccination

BCG vaccination is offered to all staff who will have direct patient contact or contact with clinical materials. Although the benefits of the BCG vaccine wane over 10-15 years repeat vaccination is not recommended.

The BCG offers approximately 80% protection, but its benefits are less clear in those over the age of 35. Despite this, NICE recommend BCG is given to HCWs regardless of age for whom there is no evidence of previous BCG vaccination, and where there are no contraindications.
Contraindications:
Those with a past history of TB.
Those with a confirmed anaphylactic reaction to a component of the vaccine.
Those receiving systemic corticosteroid or other immunosuppressive therapy, including general radiation.
Those suffering diseases or malignant conditions in which the normal immunological mechanisms might be impaired.
Those known or suspected to be HIV positive.
Those with feverish illness.
Those with generalised septic skin conditions.
Those who are pregnant.
Those in whom more than 3 months has elapsed since a Mantoux test was undertaken.
Those who have received live vaccinations within preceding 4 weeks.
Information for HCWs
HCWs who are exposed to TB as part of their routine work should receive annual reminders about the condition. An information leaflet can be found at appendix
HCWs who are exposed to a case of infectious TB either in a patient or HCW should receive the same advice.

HCWs who are HIV positive are at increased risk of becoming infected with TB; a risk assessment should determine whether they should avoid working in areas where the risk of exposure to TB is increased. HIV positive HCWs need to be reminded of the symptoms of TB. HCWs who have HIV or think they may be at risk of having HIV should be screened for HIV before being offered the BCG. If HIV testing is declined, BCG should not be given, due to the potential risks outweighing the benefits.
Fitness to work
Pre-placement health checks, including Tuberculosis, should be completed before the employee starts work. See Appendix

HCWs who become infected with active pulmonary TB should refrain from work for two weeks after commencing treatment. Thereafter, they are deemed to be non- infectious, and may return if they feel well enough to work. Liaison with the Infection Control Team, treating Physician and TB Clinical Nurse Specialist will be a normal part of this assessment.
Refusal of BCG vaccination
If BCG vaccination is refused, the risks should be explained and the refusal recorded.

The employer will need to consider each case individually, taking account of employment and health and safety obligations and in some cases, restriction may not be warranted. An annual information sheet should be provided to the employee to maintain awareness to symptoms suggestive of active disease. See appendix 4.
Prevention
Section 6.1 looks at the tests available to clarify the presence of TB and section 6.2 defines the different groups requiring testing, as not all tests are required by every group.
Tests for TB
6.1.1 Questionnaire
The protection of staff begins with pre-placement screening. The screening questionnaire is used for  all  new employees as part of the pre-placement assessment process.
The questionnaire includes questions on:
Symptom screen. (Persistent cough >3 weeks, haemoptysis, weight loss, night sweats, fever)
Personal history of TB
Family history of TB
Travel to endemic countries (see section 5.2.1 for definition).
A screening questionnaire should also be sent annually to those working in high-risk areas, together with a TB information sheet.
High risk areas include:
TB clinic
Microbiology and Histopathology Lab
ITU
Bronchoscopy Unit
HIV units
Respiratory Wards
6.1.2 Mantoux testing

The Mantoux test is used as a screening test for TB infection or disease. It provides an assessment of an individual's sensitivity to TB. The greater the reaction, the greater the likelihood of active TB.

All staff likely to come into contact with patients or samples of tissue/ body fluids should undergo TB assessment. This assessment will include a Mantoux test unless one of the following exclusion criteria is met:

The HCW has a BCG scar, and has not visited a high prevalence area for more than one month in the last 5 years. A BCG scar check should be carried out by an occupational health professional and should not rely on the employee's personal assessment.
Previously treated TB
Known hypersensitivity to Mantoux
Documentary evidence that confirms BCG has been given.
The HCW has documented evidence of strongly positive response to TST in the past.
Documented positive TST in the last 5 years.
Any known factors likely to cause suppression (see below), this is not a contra- indication, however it increases the likelihood of a false negative result.
The full procedure for carrying out Mantoux testing is outlined in Appendix  Suppression of the test can be caused by various factors. These include:
Co-administration of live vaccines, such as MMR or Varicella. Therefore, MMR or Varicella should either be given more than 4 weeks in advance, or delayed until the Mantoux reading has occurred.
Immune suppression, such as HIV infection
Other viral illness, such as URTI or Glandular Fever
Steroid therapy
Sarcoidosis
If a possible explanation for a poor reaction can be identified, the Mantoux test should be repeated on the other forearm, 2-3 weeks later.
The Mantoux reading is ideally 48-72 hours post-administration, but can be read up to 96 hours later. The diameter of induration (NOT erythema) should be measured
and recorded in mm, using a ruler. As different results have different meanings, it should not simply be recorded as positive/negative. The interpretation of the Mantoux is outlined in Appendix 1,
6.1.3 Immunological testing
A second method of demonstrating potential infection (latent TB) is the blood-based immunological test (Interferon Gamma Test, IGT).
6.1.4 Chest X-Ray (CXR)
A CXR result is required for those who have lived in a high prevalence country for greater than one month in the last 5 years. A Radiologist should interpret the CXR.
Different groups of employees requiring testing
6.2.1 New Employees to the NHS with clinical contact, coming from Endemic (high prevalence) Areas.

Individuals who have lived or worked in countries where TB is endemic for more than one month in the last 5 years need careful assessment as the risk of TB is considerably higher. An endemic country is one where the annual incidence exceeds 40/100,000. An up to date list is available online at www.hpa.org.uk, also see references. It broadly includes all countries outside of Western Europe, North America, Australia and New Zealand.
Testing criteria:
Pre-placement health screening
IGT (T-Spot)
Mantoux (see 5.1.2 for exclusion criteria).
6.2.2 New Employees to the NHS with Clinical Contact coming from non-endemic countries
Testing criteria:
Pre-placement health screening
Mantoux (see 5.1.2 for exclusion criteria).
6.2.3 New Employees without Clinical Contact Testing criteria:
Pre-placement health screening only
6.2.4 Existing employees returning to the UK following a prolonged period visiting an Endemic  Area.

Existing employees who have travelled and visited a high prevalence area for one month or more should present themselves to Occupational Health on return to work so that a symptom questionnaire can be completed and a T-spot test undertaken. They are fit to remain in work whilst awaiting the results of the test.
Exposure to case of open TB

HCWs who have been significantly exposed to a case of TB will need to be assessed and be provided with an information sheet outlining the symptoms of TB. Determining significant exposure and the need for screening should be coordinated by Occupational Health in conjunction with the ward/department manager, the Infection Control team and the TB Specialist Nurse. Factors to take into consideration include:
The degree of infectivity of the index case
The length of time before the infectious patient was isolated and whether they were isolated in a negative pressure room.
Whether PPE was worn when in close contact with patient
The proximity of contact - greater than 8 hours in the same room, or high risk procedures, such as mouth-to-mouth resuscitation and chest physiotherapy are all deemed to be significant exposure.
Whether the HCW is at increased risk due to factors such as
immunosuppression.
Training requirements
Staff will receive information on TB at the following times during employment:
As part of the Occupational Health / Trust induction;
During occupational health screening.
Reminders  of  the  symptoms  of  TB  and  reporting  such  symptoms  should  be included with annual reminders for staff who:
Are in regular contact with TB patients or clinical materials;
Have worked in a high-risk clinical setting for 4 weeks or longer.

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Infection Prevention and Control Committee which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local  guidelines and  policies.  These  will  then  be  forwarded  to  the  Document control team for  submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the HR working Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.

data.text: Appendix 2: Information sheet about TB for healthcare workers
What is TB?
Tuberculosis (TB) is an infectious disease caused by a bacterium called Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It usually affects the lungs (pulmonary TB) but can affect other parts of the body.
What are the symptoms of TB?
The most common form of TB is pulmonary TB. A person with TB of the lung will usually:
How is TB spread?
TB can only be spread by people with infectious TB in the lungs or larynx. How difficult is it to catch TB?
TB is quite difficult to catch and usually requires prolonged or repeated contact with a person with infectious TB. Infectious TB is usually taken to mean an individual where
Mycobacterium tuberculosis is demonstrated in that individual's sputum when looked at under the microscope. Prolonged or repeated contact is usually taken to mean living in the same household.

In an occupational health care setting a contact is defined as any healthcare worker who has been within coughing distance of an infectious individual – about two to three feet. These ‘at risk' staff are then classified as either ‘close contacts' or ‘casual contacts'. Very few occupational contacts are defined as close contacts, which is the risk equivalent of household contacts. These are staff undertaking mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, care of a high dependency patient (more than eight hours cumulative), repeated chest physiotherapy or sputum induction procedures.

Most occupational contacts are casual. Casual contacts in general do not require screening. The exception is if the health care worker is immunosuppressed or if the patient is thought to be highly infectious.
What is the difference between TB disease and latent TB?
For most people who become infected with TB, the immune system is able to fight the bacteria and eliminate them or stop them growing. If the bacteria become inactivated then this is called latent TB.
People with latent TB have no symptoms, do not feel unwell, are not infectious, but can develop TB disease later in life. People with TB disease have symptoms of the disease.
What is BCG vaccine?

This is a modified strain of Mycobacterium bovis, the bacterium that causes TB in cattle. The bacteria in the vaccine are alive but have been modified so that they do not cause disease. This helps to protect against TB, but not in all cases. It works best against the most severe forms of disease in children, such as TB meningitis. BCG is given only once as a single injection into the skin.
Why do some people have a skin test before the BCG vaccine?

This is to determine whether the immune system already recognises TB. It involves injecting a small amount of tuberculin into the skin and is called a Mantoux test. The injection site is inspected two to three days later.
Who is most at risk from TB?

Anyone can get TB but some people are more at risk. TB is increasing in the UK and is found mainly in London and in populations  who originate from countries with a high prevalence of TB. In the UK, those who are most at risk of developing TB disease are people who:
Are close contacts of a person with infectious TB

Have visited, lived or worked for a long time in countries with a high rate of TB. (Extra screening is required for those who have lived or worked in these countries for more than one month in the last five years).
Are the children of parents or grandparents whose country of origin has a high rate of TB
Have a weakened immune system due to disease (HIV) or treatment
Are homeless or living in overcrowded conditions
Have been in prison
Are addicted to drugs or alcohol
Health care workers have a low rate of TB infection but this is still higher when compared with the general population (allowing for age, sex and ethnicity).
Who do I contact if I am worried about TB?
If you have further questions, or if you think you may have any of the symptoms or been exposed to TB please contact the OH department on 01268 524900 ext
